cluster_relations.rel_desc: Governments use force as a means to suppress dissent.
Governments use force with the aim of silencing opposition.

args.canonical_rel_desc: The subject (typically a state or authority) uses coercive means to constrain, silence, or punish the political activities or expression of the object.
args.justification: Both relations describe governments using force to suppress or silence political opponents or dissenting groups. This is a coercive, intentional action by a state actor against political actors, best normalized as a single predicate 'represses'.

In both cases, governments deploy force against political challengers (dissent or opposition). These are classic instances of state repression, so they should be grouped into a relation class capturing coercive actions by the state against political actors.

The primary semantic dimension is an intentional action by an agent (the government) acting upon another actor (dissent/opposition). While there is a causal aspect (using force to achieve repression), the core is an agentive relation: one actor exercising power over another.
